abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Biallelic <jats:italic>PNKP</jats:italic> variants cause heterogeneous disorders ranging from neurodevelopmental disorder with microcephaly/seizures to adult-onset Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease. To date, only postnatal descriptions exist. We present the first prenatal diagnosis of <jats:italic>PNKP</jats:italic>-related primary microcephaly. Pathological examination of a male fetus in the 18th gestational week revealed micrencephaly with extracerebral malformations and thus presumed syndromic microcephaly. A recessive disorder was suspected because of previous pregnancy termination for similar abnormalities. Prenatal trio-exome sequencing identified compound heterozygosity for the <jats:italic>PNKP</jats:italic> variants c.498G>A, p.[(=),0?] and c.302C>T, p.(Pro101Leu). Segregation confirmed both variants in the sister fetus. Through RNA analyses, we characterized exon 4 skipping affecting the <jats:italic>PNKP</jats:italic> forkhead-associated (FHA) and phosphatase domains (p.Leu67_Lys166del) as the predominant effect of the paternal c.498G>A variant. We retrospectively investigated two unrelated individuals diagnosed with biallelic <jats:italic>PNKP</jats:italic>-variants to compare prenatal/postnatal phenotypes. Both carry the splice donor variant c.1029+2T>C <jats:italic>in</jats:italic><jats:italic>trans</jats:italic> with a variant in the FHA domain (c.311T>C, p.(Leu104Pro); c.151G>C, p.(Val51Leu)). RNA-seq showed complex splicing for c.1029+2T>C and c.151G>C. Structural modeling revealed significant clustering of missense variants in the FHA domain with variants generating structural damage. Our clinical description extends the <jats:italic>PNKP</jats:italic>-continuum to the prenatal stage. Investigating possible <jats:italic>PNKP</jats:italic>-variant effects using RNA and structural modeling, we highlight the mutational complexity and exemplify a <jats:italic>PNKP</jats:italic>-variant characterization framework.</jats:p>

assertion.value: The authors declare no competing interests.

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The Ethical Committee of the Medical Faculty, Leipzig University, approved genetic testing in a research setting for all probands (224/16-ek and 402/16-ek). Written consent of the parents to publish genetic and clinical data, postmortem images (P1, P2), sonography (P1, P2), and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) (P1, P3, and P4) was received and archived by the authors.
